Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43361  
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
September 2010 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Water and Sanitation Services 
and Planning Improvement 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 3 September 2010) 
 
Currency Unit –  togrog (MNT) 
MNT1.00 =  $0.00075 
$1.00 =  MNT1,324 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GIS  –  geographic information system  
  JICA    Japan International Cooperation Agency 
  MUB  –  Municipality of Ulaanbaatar 
  O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
  PPP  –  public–private partnership 
  USUG  –  Ulaanbaatar water and sewerage company 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services 
(water supply and sanitation, other municipal services, urban 
sector development, slum upgrading and housing) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Environmental  sustainability  (urban  environmental 
improvement),  private  sector  development  (public–private 
partnerships),  capacity  development  (organizational 
development) 
Location impact  –  Rural (low), urban (high), national (medium), regional (medium) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  A. Leung, Urban and Social Sectors Division, EARD

Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) for the improvement of water and 
sanitation services and planning in Ulaanbaatar is directly linked to the Urban Sector Roadmap 
for Mongolia of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The road map recommends investment 
where the potential return is greatest and Ulaanbaatar is singled out as a key target area. The 
plan will focus assistance on (i) improving urban planning and management; (ii) enhancing 
infrastructure service prioritization, planning, and maintenance; and (iii) developing innovative 
approaches to attract private sector in providing urban services. An ADB fact-finding mission 
visited Ulaanbaatar from 29 March to 2 April 2010 in preparation for this TA. A memorandum of 
understanding between the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB) and ADB was signed on 2 April 
2010. It reflected the mission’s latest findings and understandings reached with the Government 
of  Mongolia  on  the  objective,  impact,  outcome,  output,  scope,  cost,  and  implementation 
arrangements for the TA.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Ulaanbaatar’s3 urban fabric is divided into two distinct parts. The formal or core area 
consists largely of apartment blocks that date back to the socialist era and have full utility 
services, including dedicated heating, hot water, and sanitation systems. The ger areas, named 
after the ger, the traditional Mongol tent, are large expanding unplanned areas with unserviced 
plots, unpaved roads, and scant facilities.4 Recent urban development in Ulaanbaatar has been 
characterized by (i) the rapid spread of these ger areas over the outskirts of the city; (ii) the 
occupation by growing numbers of ger residents of dangerous and marginal sites such as along 
storm water channels and beneath high voltage power lines; (iii) the rapid and unplanned 
development of new apartment areas that have dated infrastructure networks, facilities, and 
management systems and are unsupported by a needed expansion of infrastructure; and (iv) 
the unauthorized encroachment by private developments into protected natural areas around 
the city. Ulaanbaatar is now struggling to improve its obsolete infrastructure in the core city 
center and to cope with the demand for better service facilities in both the core and the ger 
areas. 
 
3.  Underinvestment in infrastructure and substandard operation and maintenance (O&M) 
raise the cost of doing business and restrict access to jobs and services. Compared with 
planned  areas,  the  adjacent  ger  areas  and  the  urban  poor  who  reside  in  them  suffer 
disproportionately  from  poor  management  and  maintenance  and  an  overall  lack  of  urban 
infrastructure and basic urban services.5 Residents are more exposed than others in the city to 
the risks associated with unsafe water supply, inadequate sanitation, insufficient heating, and an 
absence of suitable roads. Most of the formal areas in Ulaanbaatar are serviced by sewerage 
systems that connect to wastewater treatment plants. Only part of this wastewater is fully 
treated due to inadequate plant O&M and the untreated or partially treated wastewater is 
discharged into  rivers,  other  watercourses,  or  directly  into  the  ground,  contaminating  local 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Review of Investment Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation—Mongolia: Urban Sector Roadmap. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 July 2010. 
3  The city grew from about 600,000 people in 1989 to over 1.03 million in 2007, representing 39% of the nation’s 
population. 
4  There are three types of ger areas: (i) central ger areas (located near the built-up core of the city, with high 
potential to access infrastructure and services); (ii) middle ger areas (those that relied on “tinkered” water supply, 
pit latrines, poor roads, and waste collection); and (iii) peri-urban ger areas (characterized by day-to-day spatial 
expansion at the urban periphery with little or no access to infrastructure or services). 
5  The urban poor are estimated to number over 250,000.

2   
surface  and  groundwater  resources.  The  ger  areas  lack  water  services  and  have  no 
comprehensive sewerage. Most residents use open pit latrines or open field defecation. Only a 
few have septic tanks. Minimal strategic and long-term planning and little land-use regulation 
results in haphazard development and little space for providing community facilities. These 
conditions threaten environmental and public health safety, lead to an elevated incidence of 
contagious disease,6 reduce livelihood security, and heighten inequalities within communities 
and the overall population. Several projects have dealt with the sanitation challenges but none 
has produced a viable, sustainable solution that can be replicated throughout the ger areas. 
 
4.  The city’s current list of proposed infrastructure investments is much larger than it can 
support. It also lacks resources to operate and maintain existing infrastructure. A number of 
planned  investments  will  most  likely  yield  low  economic  returns.  Without  reforms  and 
prioritization, infrastructure will become a development constraint. A planned ADB initiative to 
improve sector governance and pricing, combined with an investment program aimed at poverty 
reduction and high economic returns, will help make the infrastructure sector a catalyst for 
growth  and  broad-based  development.  Current  investment  plans  must  be  examined  and 
improved to make projects feasible and to achieve the greatest impact possible on economic 
growth and poverty reduction. Approaches that maximize participation by the private sector and 
civil society should also be introduced. In 2012, ADB plans to develop a loan to finance urban 
services infrastructure. It has stressed the need to explore new areas for ADB lending and 
nonlending  operations  in  Ulaanbaatar's  urban  sector.  The  most  critical  sectors  for  urban 
development and livelihood improvement right now are water, sanitation, and improvement of 
the ger areas.7 Both the government and the public accord them the highest priority. The 
creation of a quality pipeline of investments in urban infrastructure and services, along with 
relevant TA, capacity building, policy dialogue, and knowledge products on the water and 
sanitation sector, will be a crucial step toward generating the greatest impact possible from 
ADB’s investments and to ensuring real improvements and operational sustainability in the two 
targeted sectors. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The impact of the TA is improved water and sanitation services in Ulaanbaatar. The 
outcome of the TA includes an integrated road map for Ulaanbaatar’s water and sanitation 
sector.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The TA will identify potential areas for ADB lending in urban services and will provide 
key policy recommendations to improve services and regulations in the planning, delivery, and 
coverage of municipal infrastructure services. The TA will focus on water and sanitation services 
and  ger  areas.  The  road  map  will  be  built  on  experiences  of  ADB,  other  donors,  and 
international organizations in water, sanitation and ger areas development.8 The main lessons 
learned  from  past  interventions  show  that  institutional  and  capacity  weaknesses  are  key 
                                                 
6  Unsafe water and unsafe hygiene practices are the main causes of diarrhea, which is closely linked to child 
malnutrition, morbidity, and mortality. 
7  Water and sanitation services are covered by the Ulaanbaatar water and sewerage company. 
8  Key donors active in Ulaanbaatar’s urban sector are the World Bank (water supply in peri-urban areas, ger area 
improvements and heating), JICA (masterplan, solid waste management and ger area improvements), UN-Habitat 
(pilots for ger area improvements), GTZ (pilots for ger area improvements and energy-efficient housing), UNDP 
(urban governance), USAID (housing), and SIDA (land management and administration).

3
constraints; and social environment and consultation, close dialogue with the Government, and 
integration into the urban planning and development are key parameters for project design. 
Based on those previous experiences the road map will be: (i) demand-driven and participatory 
in approach, (ii) based on a long-term development vision for the city and an analysis of the 
city's competitive advantages, (iii) assessed not only in terms of the sector but also in the 
broader context of urban development, (iv) integrated in the local or city master plan, (v) closely 
coordinated  with  the  Government  and  other  donors  activities,  and  (vi)  will  early  identify 
institutional and capacity issues for an efficient implementation of the road map investments. 
The TA will help ADB act as a strong partner in policy dialogue at multiple levels of government 
and foster strategic partnerships with the private sector and bilateral donors. 
 
7.  The TA will (i) undertake a strategic and operationally linked urban analysis to create 
innovative  approaches,  blend  knowledge  with  lending,9and  develop  regulation  and  policy 
reforms, focusing  on water and sanitation and the improvement of ger areas; (ii) select key 
subsectors (related to water and sanitation and the improvement of ger areas) and provide a list 
of priority quality infrastructure investments, based on environmental sustainability, a high social 
impact  and economic rate of return, good human resource development, and a pro-poor focus; 
(iii) develop an urban services road map and a pipeline of quality projects suitable for financing 
by ADB10 and the private sector over 5–10 years; (iv) rank and provide recommendations on the 
institutional reforms, technical support, and policy dialogue needed to improve the legal and 
institutional  environment  to  ensure  that  the  ADB  lending  program  will  be  effective  and 
sustainable; (v) present and build a business case for private sector participation in the water 
and  sanitation  sector;11 (vi)  outline  a  public  participation  framework  to  help  prioritize  and 
maintain services in ger areas; (vii) optimize synergies between various assistance modalities, 
bilateral resources, and the private sector; and (viii) develop project concept notes in selected 
subsectors that will reduce start-up delays in a project preparatory TA planned for 2011. 
 
8.  The TA to be implemented over 9 months has three components. 
 
9.  Component  1  (September–November  2010). Planning and sector analysis will (a) 
review the existing master plan and fully assess urban development expertise and infrastructure 
bottlenecks;12 (b) make recommendations for urban and infrastructure planning principles, the 
enhancing O&M of existing facilities, and the use of geographic information system applications 
to  assist  in  decision  making  and  regulation  of  land  use;13 (c)  formulate  a  future  urban 
development pattern and vision; (d) design a matrix to identify and develop priority subsectors in 
water and sanitation and ger area improvement by highlighting their potentials for ADB business 
operation; 14  and  (e)  identify  the  road  map’s  social  criteria  to  support  inclusive  urban 
development and establish a framework for public participation in choosing priority investments. 
At the end of component 1, a tripartite meeting will be held between the executing agency 
(MUB), ADB, and stakeholders to validate the core subsector for the urban services road map. 
                                                 
9  The TA will identify a set of relevant knowledge product proposals from the investment program to disseminate 
knowledge and best practices, including an in-depth study of key innovative program initiatives. 
10  Different lending modalities will be envisaged, such as a multitranche financing facility. 
11 This activity will refer to a pilot case for public–private partnerships (PPP) in the water and sanitation area 
previously developed for ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Grant to Mongolia for the Southeast Gobi Urban and Border Town Development Project. Manila (Grant 
0204-MON). 
12 The TA will coordinate closely on this with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) team, especially 
regarding the ongoing urban master plan revision for Ulaanbaatar. 
13 The consultant will refer to ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Loan and Technical Assistance Grant to Mongolia for the Cadastral Survey and Land Registration 
Project. Manila (Loan 1736-MON and TA 3395-MON). 
14 This is to be undertaken in cooperation with JICA, which is also supporting development of the same area.

4   
10.  Component 2 (November 2010–May 2011). The policy and reform framework will (a) 
consolidate the road map in the selected subsector; (b) make recommendations on the key 
issues of pricing, planning, land use and land acquisition,15 as well as on the opportunities for 
private sector participation,16 improvements in infrastructure maintenance, and the institutional 
reform  necessary  to  execute  and  sustain  the  road  map;  (c)  establish  a  plan  for  priority 
knowledge products,17 policy dialogues, capacity building,18 and TA relevant to the targeted 
subsector; (d) identify and integrate initiatives from other donors, international organizations, 
and  the  government;  and  (e)  develop  urban  indicators  linked  to  urban-related  Millennium 
Development Goals for monitoring the outcomes and outputs of the road map.  
 
11.  Component 3 (December 2010–March 2011). The investment plan will (a) define with 
ADB and the government counterpart priority infrastructure investments in the subsector road 
map to be included in the project preparatory TA for 2011; (b) prepare a series of project 
investment  proposals  at  the  concept  paper  stage,  including  preliminary  technical  criteria, 
environmental  assessment,  social  safeguards  and  analysis,  and  financial  and  economic 
assessments; and (c) identify priority TA, knowledge products, and complementary projects to 
be financed by ADB, the private sector, and other funds or partners. 
 
12.  Because the TA components and the nature and scope of the subsectors will be clarified 
during TA implementation, provision will be made for supplementary individual consultants to 
either consolidate the expertise already available or supplement the needed expertise. Three 
workshops will disseminate the findings of each component and assure that stakeholders take 
part in selecting investment proposals and institutional reforms.  The main potential risks to TA 
performance include (i) a government reluctance to accept the proposed investment program, (ii) 
a  lack  of  cooperation  from  other  donors  and  stakeholders,  (iii)  inadequate  support  and 
performance from the government and stakeholders, and (iv) insufficient or late delivery of data. 
The TA will mitigate these risks through the consultative approach and by working closely with 
the MUB and the Ulaanbaatar Water and Sewerage Company to get the data and information it 
needs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $670,000, of which $600,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, to be administered by ADB. 
The Government of Mongolia will provide in-kind support equivalent to $70,000 by providing 
office  space  and  equipment,  office  communications,  and  remuneration  and  per  diem  for 
counterpart staff. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The MUB, which has been a partner in other ADB and World Bank projects, will be the 
executing and implementing agency.  The MUB needs consulting support, strategic advice, and 
                                                 
15 The  work  will  coordinate  with  ADB’s  subproject  on  strengthening  of  safeguards  for  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement in Mongolia. ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard 
Systems. Manila (TA 7566-REG, July 2010)/subproject on strengthening of safeguard for land acquisition and 
resettlement in Mongolia. 
16 The TA will coordinate with ADB’s Public–Private Partnership Development Project (for 2010 approval) to improve 
the legal framework for PPP and to support the newly established department of PPP and concession, State 
Property Committee. 
17 The team leader  will take the lead in coordinating inputs for and developing the knowledge products plan. 
18 This plan will build on past experiences in policy dialogue and capacity-building efforts. The TA will learn from 
implementation problems encountered in the past. ADB. 1997. Report and Recommendation of the President to the 
Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for the Ulaanbaatar Heat Efficiency. Manila (Loan 1548-MON).

5
capacity development to define an ensuing project that will be prepared under a future project 
preparatory TA.  The current TA will be implemented over 9 months and is expected to start in 
September 2010 and to be completed by the end of May 2011. The TA will finance consulting 
services, workshops, training, field work, and survey costs. It will require an estimated 47 
person-months of consulting services—17 person-months of international consultants and 30 
person-months of national consultants. The main fields of expertise will be urban planning, 
municipal infrastructure, water and sanitation, safeguards, finance and economics, and private 
sector  participation.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended time to time). 
 
15.  The consultants for component 1 or those hired through the supplementary provision for 
consultants will be engaged as individual consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Individual  international 
consultants  (7  person-months)  will  be  supported  by  four  national  consultants  (12  person-
months). The supplementary individual consultants will provide an estimated 3 person-months 
of consultancy, distributed as 1 person-month of international consultancy and supported by 2 
person-months of national consultancy. The use of individual consultants is justified because 
component 1 is an exploratory phase involving a preliminary analysis of strategic management 
decisions. Each consultant is expected to explore a full range of approaches in a distinctive field 
of expertise and, taking into consideration the complexity of urban development in Ulaanbaatar, 
propose  innovative,  feasible  directions  for  integrated  development  linked  with  water  and 
sanitation service. Component 1 will be closely supervised by ADB’s TA team, which has 
experience in Mongolia in urban strategic study, infrastructure programming, and social issues. 
Under the direct coordination of ADB’s task manager for the project, each individual consultant 
will work closely with the infrastructure specialist to consolidate efforts with those of the other 
individual consultants. The preparation, quality control, and submission of the strategic reports 
will be the responsibility of the infrastructure specialist. This approach will also permit early 
mobilization of the consultants, preventing a delay in the delivery of the TA outputs necessary to 
start the 2011 project preparatory TA in the first quarter of 2011. Prompt deployment will avoid 
the difficult working conditions imposed by the harsh Mongolian winter. 
 
16.  The consultants for components 2 and 3 will be engaged through a consulting firm in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  A  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  for  9  person-months  of  international  consultancy 
supported by 16 person-months of national consultancy. The firm will be selected based on the 
quality- and cost- based selection method, using a 90:10 ratio. The heavy weighting on the 
quality of the proposal is considered appropriate because of the complexity of the environment 
for strategic options in the delivery and financing of basic urban services. ADB's simplified 
technical proposal will be used to select and engage the consultants. The equipment for TA 
implementation will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time) and will be turned over to MUB after completion of the TA. The 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Ulaanbaatar Water and Sanitation Services and Planning Improvement, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants  for  Component  1:  Planning  and  Sector  Analysis  (September–
November 2010) 
1.  Component 1 will be implemented by a team of four individual international consultants 
(7 person-months) supported by four national consultants (12 person-months): (i) infrastructure 
specialist (2 person-months international, 3 person-months national); (ii) urban planner or urban 
geographer (2 person-months international, 3 person-months national); (iii) water and sanitation 
expert (1.5 person-months international, 3 person-months national); and (iv) social development 
specialist (1.5 person-months international, 3 person-months national). The consultants will 
coordinate directly with the task manager for the project of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The consultants for component 1 will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). After completion of component 1, 
individual  consultants  will  continue  to  provide  their  inputs  to  ensure  the  completion  of 
components 2 and 3. 
 
2.  The consultants will (i) prepare and submit an inception report 1 month after consultant 
mobilization, a draft strategic report 2 months after consultant mobilization, and a final strategic 
report 3 months after the mobilization of individual consultants; (ii) organize a workshop to 
discuss  the  main  findings  of  the  strategic  report  and  a  tripartite  meeting  to  agree  on  the 
selection of  a potential urban services subsector investment package to be included in the road 
map; and (iii) provide technical input for components 2 and 3. 
 
3.  All reports will be written in English and translated into Mongolian. Three copies of each 
report (in English) will be submitted to ADB and 10 copies (in both Mongolian and English) to 
the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB), the executing agency. The consultant will present key 
findings in four workshops. Members of the Mongolia and Ulaanbaatar governments, the MUB, 
key agencies, local communities, and ADB staff will participate in the workshops. In parallel, 
tripartite meetings will be organized after the submission and review of the strategic report, the 
inception report, the interim report, and the final draft report. The consultants will assist ADB in 
the preparation of the draft technical assistance (TA) report. 
 
4.  Infrastructure specialist. The consultant should have at least 15 years of experience in 
municipal  infrastructure  and  extensive  experience  in  infrastructure  programming,  municipal 
engineering, urban rehabilitation, and urban services provision in developing countries with a 
relevant postgraduate degree. For component 1, the consultant will (i) assess the capacity and 
constraints to current utility services according to current and future infrastructure demand in 
services provision; (ii) develop a matrix to define priority urban services subsectors; (iii) identify 
and review experiences of ADB,1 other donors, and international organizations in water and 
                                                 
1  Lessons learned provided in the urban services sector from previous ADB-financed urban loans: (i) ADB. 1997. 
Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for the 
Ulaanbaatar Heat Efficiency. Manila (Loan 1548-MON); (ii) ADB. 1997. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical Assistance Grant to Mongolia for the Provincial 
Towns Basic Urban Services Project. Manila (Loan 1560-MON); (iii) ADB. 2001. Report and Recommendation of 
the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for the Housing Finance (Sector) Project. 
Manila (Loan 1847-MON); (iv) ADB. 2002. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Loan to Mongolia for the Integrated Development of Basic Urban Services in Provincial Towns Project. 
Manila (Loan 1907-MON); (v) ADB. 2006. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Loan to Mongolia for the Urban Development Sector Project. Manila (Loan 2301-MON); and (vi) ADB. 
2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to Mongolia for the 
Southeast Gobi Urban and Border Town Development Project. Manila (Grant 0204-MON).

Appendix 3  11 
sanitation, as well as identify best practices and possible cooperation in the sector; (iv) develop 
at least four different sets of investment packages to reflect different types of priorities and 
subsectors, including two packages focusing on urban services in ger areas; (v), investigate 
alternative technologies of infrastructure for ger areas (water supply, sanitation, solid waste 
management,  heating,  hot  water  supply,  roads,  and  storm  water  drainage),  considering 
environmental impacts, costs, affordability, institutional arrangements, and social priority; (vi) 
recommend appropriate institutional arrangements for planning and managing urban facilities in 
the  identified  subsectors;  (vii)  identify  measurable  indicators  for  subsector  outcomes  and 
outputs in addition to the investment and intervention package; (viii) be responsible for the 
organization, quality, and submission of the strategic reports; and (ix) provide technical inputs 
for the finalization of the urban services road map and project concept note for 2011 project 
preparatory TA. 
 
5.  Urban  planner/urban  geographer.  The  consultant  should  have  at  least  15  years 
experience in urban planning in developing countries. He or she should have a strong academic 
background with relevant PhD and possess expertise in developing conceptual tools in urban 
planning  and  land-use  principles  and  have  led  several  urban  or  regional  master  planning 
undertakings. The consultant should also be familiar with urban demographics, e.g., urban–rural 
migration, urban population growth, and urban development patterns. For component 1, the 
consultant’s  specific  tasks  will  be  to  (i)  review  the  existing  city  and  district  master  plans, 
especially  those  developed  by  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  assess  their 
medium- and long-term objectives, and develop intermediary stages of urban development to 
achieve these objectives; (ii) produce an analytic and strategic urban framework highlighting 
land-use patterns, with due consideration to forces and directions of urban growth; (iii) develop 
recommendations  for  redirecting  urban  growth  to  achieve  economy  and  efficiency  in 
infrastructure and services provision and assess the densification process in the ger areas; (iv) 
evaluate urban planning mechanisms, policies, and organizational frameworks; (v) develop 
recommendations to improve and enforce master plans and planning principles and strengthen  
land use and institutions; and (vi) assess the geographic information system (GIS) capacity of 
the city and provide recommendations to enhance capabilities in GIS applications,2 highlighting 
its use in decision making, land-use regulation,3 and the efficiency and transparency of the 
urban planning process. 
 
6.  Water/sanitation expert. The consultant should have at least 10 years experience in 
the water and sanitation sector and 5 years of work experience in Ulaanbaatar, with a relevant 
postgraduate degree. He or she should be familiar with technical, institutional, and financial 
aspects of water and sanitation in Mongolia. Experience in working with the Ulaanbaatar water 
and sewerage company (USUG)  will be an advantage. The consultant’s specific tasks for 
component 1 will be to  (i) identify the most appropriate technologies and approaches for water 
supply, sanitation, and other services, such as storm water drainage; (ii) assess institutional 
reform and policy recommendations related to water and sanitation; (iii) review the needs for 
financial and organizational development of USUG; (iv) assess the management, maintenance, 
and operational efficiency of USUG; (v) examine alternative technologies suited to Mongolia’s 
cold  climate;  (vi)  assess  service  network  efficiency  and  recommend  measures  to  prevent 
physical and commercial losses and to maximize the use of available water; (vii) measure the 
                                                 
2  The consultant will coordinate with the ongoing TA 7297-MON: Road Database Development Using Geographic 
Information System. 
3  The consultant will refer to ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Loan and Technical Assistance Grant to Mongolia for the Cadastral Survey and Land Registration 
Project.  Manila (Loan 1736-MON and TA 3395-MON).

12  Appendix 3 
 
proposed road map’s impact on water and sanitation services; (viii) assess the possibility and 
the benefit of upgrading the management and operation of technological tools such as GIS, 
especially in managing demand, expanding supply, and ensuring water quality and wastewater 
collection  efficiency;  and  (ix)  with  the  infrastructure  expert,  prepare  preliminary  technical 
specifications for core subprojects investment, including estimated project cost. 
 
7.  Social  development  specialist.  The  consultant  should  have  at  least  15  years  of 
experience  in  social  development,  specializing  in  urban  upgrading  and  community-based 
approaches to urban services provision, with a relevant postgraduate degree. The consultant’s 
specific task for component 1 will be to (i) identify the social criteria for the road map, focusing 
on  ger  areas;  (ii)  identify  best  practices  for  community-based  urban  services  provision  in 
Mongolia; (iii) investigate community payment, management, and maintenance schemes for 
water and sanitation services and consult to gather local perceptions of drivers and directions of 
growth, densification, spatial preferences, etc. in ger areas; (iv) prepare a public participation 
plan for investment prioritization in ger areas and assess potential for including urban planning  
social dimensions in the GIS; (v) carry out in-depth analysis of the poverty, gender and other 
social impacts of the road map and come up with recommendations to increase benefits for the 
poor; (vi) develop the social criteria for the project component selection; (vii) conduct focus 
group  meetings  with  community-based  organizations  and  ger  area  residents  to  discuss 
infrastructure options and willingness to pay, prepare a community and civic society involvement 
participation  strategy,  and  develop  a  mechanism  to  promote  community  participation  in 
prioritization, planning, monitoring, management, and evaluation; (viii) review ongoing ADB 
projects under implementation and identify social issues and constraints; (ix) prepare an initial 
poverty and social assessment for the project concept note; and (x) develop education and 
training  programs  to  increase  people’s  awareness  on  public  health  and  environmental 
management, and to ensure community participation in the operation and maintenance of the 
improved urban infrastructure.  
 
B.  Consultants for Component 2 (Policy and Reform Framework, November 2010–
May 2011) and Component 3 (Investment Plan, December 2010–March 2011) 
8.  A  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  for  9  person-months  of  international  consultancy 
supported  by  16  person-months  of  national  consultancy:  (i)  team  leader/municipal 
engineer/institutional specialist (4 person-months international, 6 person-months national); (ii) 
economic and finance specialist (1.5 person-months international, 3 person-months national); (iii) 
resettlement  specialist  (1  person-month  international,  2  person-months  national);  (iv) 
environment specialist (1 person-month international, 2 person-months national); and (v) private 
sector/public–private partnership (PPP) specialist (1.5 person-months international, 3 person-
months national). The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants. Individual consultants for component 1 will provide their inputs to jointly 
complete  the  tasks  of  the  consulting  firm.  The  consulting  firm  will  perform  the  tasks  of 
components 2 and 3 as described in the TA report main text (para. 8) under the guidance of the 
ADB project team: 
 
9.  The consultant firm shall prepare and submit: (i) an inception report within 1 month after 
firm mobilization, (ii) an interim report at the end of month 3 after the commencement of 
services, and (iii) a draft final report at the end of month 5 after the commencement of services. 
The report will comprise (i) all the findings and recommendations, and (ii) the complete set of 
project proposals for ADB financing. The final report will be submitted within 1 month after 
receiving the comments on the draft final report. The report will address the comments made by 
the MUB, the implementing agency, other relevant agencies and stakeholders, and ADB. The

Appendix 3  13 
equipment for TA implementation will be procured by the consulting firm in accordance with 
ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
10.  Team leader/municipal engineer/institutional specialist. The consultant should have 
at least 15 years experience in municipal engineering in developing countries, particularly in 
Mongolia or in cold-climate countries, with a relevant postgraduate degree. The consultant must 
have excellent English writing skills and extensive experience working in ADB and/or World 
Bank projects. He or she should have a good track record in preparing good quality reports and 
facilitating workshops for lesson sharing. The consultant’s specific tasks will be to (i) finalize the 
integrated subsector road map and the project’s concept paper, assisted by the project team; (ii) 
work  with  the  water  and  sanitation  expert  and  infrastructure  specialist  to  assess  technical 
capacity  gaps  of  stakeholders  in  the  proposed  subsector  and  develop  a  capacity-building 
program; (iii) consolidate dialogue with other donors and prepare a cooperation plan based on 
component 1 recommendations; (iv) lead public consultations with relevant stakeholders and 
with the people who may be potentially affected; (v) finalize disaggregated data with clear and 
measurable  indicators  linked  to  urban-related  Millennium  Development  Goals  to  allow  the 
measurement of sector performance and of progress in achieving urban economic development 
and providing improved service; (vi) examine lessons ADB learned from previous urban loans in 
the urban services sector (footnote 1); (vii) work with the water and sanitation expert and 
infrastructure specialist to prepare technical specifications for core infrastructure investments; 
(viii)  identify  and  assess  institutional  weakness  that  will  constrain  the  timely  and  efficient 
execution of the proposal, as well as the medium- and long-term sustainability of the subsector 
road map and the asset created; (ix) make recommendations for institutional strengthening 
components to ensure smooth implementation of ADB’s urban portfolio; (x) prepare institutional 
capacity-building programs for the selected subsector road map; (xi) establish a plan for priority 
knowledge  products,  policy  dialogues,  capacity  building,  and  TA  relevant  to  the  targeted 
subsector; (xii) recommend appropriate institutional arrangements for planning and managing 
water,  drainage,  and  sanitation  facilities;  (xiii)  assess  the  capacity  of  the  Ulaanbaatar  city 
government  and  related  agencies  to  formulate  infrastructural  development  plans  and  to 
implement,  operate,  maintain,  and  manage  the  facilities  to  be  built  under  the  investment 
package; (xiv) assess and coordinate the needs of government officials, local authorities, and 
ger area communities for education and training on public health, environment, and alternative 
technologies; and (xv) supervise and finalize the TA reporting. 
 
11.  Economic  and  finance  specialist.  The  consultant  should  have  at  least  15  years 
experience in the economic and finance sector and familiarity with the water and sanitation 
sector, with a relevant postgraduate degree. The consultant’s specific tasks will be to (i) assess 
the economic and financial cost and benefit of the selected subsector road map; (ii) review the 
financial performance of service delivery and capacity of implementing agencies regarding cost 
recovery, borrowing capacity, collection of fees and taxes, accounts receivable, and subsidies, 
as appropriate; (iii) assess and provide recommendations to improve the financial sustainability 
of service provision and to enhance investments in operation and maintenance; (iv) undertake a 
financial management assessment of the MUB; (v) assess and make recommendations on 
services tariffs, particularly on transparent, equitable and efficient mechanisms for directing 
public subsidies toward the ger area where the cost of servicing is high and the population poor; 
(vi) provide recommendations for reforming pricing and regulation mechanisms in the related 
subsector, especially to align prices more closely with costs; (vii) identify areas for improvement 
and training in the financial approach to water demands,  as well as least-cost options for utility 
services;  (viii)  review  the  economic  rationale  for  the  project  concept  note  on  economic 
development plans, the urban development plan, environmental and social impacts, and other 
relevant strategic plans, and use the review results to determine the extent of further cost-

14  Appendix 3 
 
benefit analysis required; and (ix) develop sound economic indicators relevant to the subsector 
road map. 
 
12.  Resettlement specialist. The consultant should have at least 15 years experience in 
the social development and resettlement sector, with a relevant postgraduate degree. He or she 
should be familiar with resettlement and social issues in Mongolia. The consultant’s specific 
tasks will be to (i) review ongoing ADB projects under implementation and identify resettlement 
issues and constraints; (ii) assess the resettlement issues of the subsector road map and make 
recommendations on resettlement and land use to mitigate the impact and ensure the smooth 
implementation  of  the  roadmap  and  proposal;  (iii)  screen  the  core  subproject  package  for 
potential involuntary resettlement impacts from land or right-of-way acquisition, and assess the 
related  gap  in  the  current  legislation  and  develop  recommendations  to  fill  in  the  gap,  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); (iv) review the draft land acquisition 
and resettlement guideline prepared under the ADB-financed Mongolia social sector support 
program; and (v) coordinate with the capacity-development TA for strengthening and use of the 
country safeguard system subproject on strengthening of safeguards for land acquisition and 
resettlement in Mongolia.4 
 
13.  Environment specialist. The consultant should have at least 15 years of experience in 
environmental  impact  assessment  in  urban  infrastructure  development,  with  a  relevant 
postgraduate degree. Experience in Mongolia would be advantageous. The consultant’s specific 
tasks will be to (i) develop environmental criteria for selecting project components; (ii) assess 
local  requirements  for  the  MUB  documentation;  (iii)  make  a  general  assessment  of 
environmental issues in Ulaanbaatar and how the proposal will help mitigate them; (iv) assess 
the road map’s environmental impact, sustainability, and risks, as well as mitigating measures 
where appropriate; maximize the road map impact on climate change adaptation and mitigation 
and recommend areas of training, especially on environmental public awareness; (v) evaluate 
the  environmental  appropriateness  of  priority  project  proposals,  provide  the  necessary 
environment analysis and justification inputs, and design appropriate monitoring indicators; (vi) 
develop the necessary environmental components to be included in the subsector road map; 
and (vii) review and assess regulations and standards related to environmental management. 
 
14.  Private sector/public–private partnership specialist. The consultant should have at 
least 15 years experience in private sector participation, with a relevant postgraduate degree. 
Experience in Mongolia would be advantageous. The consultant’s specific tasks will be to (i) 
develop scenarios for private sector involvement and introduce approaches that maximize the 
role of private sector; (ii) coordinate with the policy and advisory TA for Mongolia for the Public–
Private  Partnership  Development  Project  (for  2010  approval);  (iii)  assess  the  benefits  of 
developing a transition plan for the water company attractive for private sector participation, and 
make recommendations; (iv) assess constraints that inhibit private sector participation in the 
selected  subsector  (e.g.,  under-pricing  of  tariffs,  regulatory  inefficiencies,  poor  physical 
infrastructure, and operational costs) and provide recommendations; (v) develop a parallel and 
complementary pipeline, related to the subsector road map, of quality projects suitable for 
private sector participation (e.g., wastewater treatment plant operations maintenance) or PPP 
(e.g., outsourcing contracts for asset management and maintenance, water distribution); and (vi) 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard Systems. Manila (TA 7566-
REG).

Appendix 3  15 
build and present a business case for private sector participation and impediments specific to 
the water sector.5 
 
C.  National Consultants 
15.  The national consultants should have at least 10 years of experience in their respective 
field of expertise, with a relevant postgraduate degree. They will be recruited to support the 
activities of international consultants in the field and to research and collect data and information 
required to achieve the terms of reference of the international consultant. Specifically, the 
national consultants will (i) collate and review national policies or standards and advise on the 
critical documents for review and translation; (ii) prepare notes, short studies, and data analysis, 
based on the direction of the international consultant; (iii) coordinate with local stakeholders 
(governments, private sector, business) to access information and arrange logistics; (iv) provide 
interpretation services for the international consultant (as required) and manage translation of 
required documents; and (v) facilitate knowledge dissemination events for sharing findings. The 
national consultants will have experience working in multidisciplinary and international technical 
assistance projects for international organizations. They will have a good command of written 
and spoken English and the experience in preparing reports in English and Mongolian. 
 
D.  Provision for Supplementary Consultants 
16.  Because the TA components and the nature and scope of the subsectors will be clarified 
during TA implementation, provision will be made for supplementary individual consultants to 
either  consolidate  the  expertise  already  available  or  supplement  the  needed  expertise. 
Individual consultants will provide an estimated 3 person-months of consultancy, distributed as 
1  person-month  of  international  consultancy  supported  by  2  person-months  of  national 
consultancy. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
                                                 
5  This activity will refer to a pilot case for PPP in the water and sanitation area developed for ADB. 2010. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to Mongolia for the Southeast Gobi 
Urban and Border Town Development Project. Manila (Grant 0204-MON).
